name: Seven Bridges Hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2006
reviews.text: This could be a charming hotel. It is conveniently located by some of the most popular art museums. Our room overlooking the canal had a great view. And the staff were helpful. Also, the breakfast brought to your room added a romantic touch (although the food was nothing special). But it needs a good cleaning (especially the carpets) and it is looking worn and a bit shabby. If this place wants to keep its reputation as one of the top guest house/small hotels, it needs to start working!
reviews.title: Needs a good cleaning! May, 2006

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2006
reviews.text: All of the nice things we read about Seven Bridges were totally true. The location is lovely on one of the prettiest canals and there are a number of good restaurants a very pleasant walk away. I chose a room not facing the canal which was a good choice during the noisy Queen's Day festivities but I'm sure that canal views would be truly delightful at any other time. We were on what we Americans call the third floor and the room (#8) was very quiet and comfortable. The rooms we saw all have charm and are well-furnished; we only wish ours had had a mini-fridge. Gunter and Pierre were very gracious hosts, helpful and fun to talk to. We really enjoyed our stay at this gem of a small hotel and would return very happily. I wish I could get that raisin bread with the marzipan here!
reviews.title: Beautiful location, charming place
Enjoying a small hotel
reviews.text: This charming small hotel is run by friendly hosts with excellent taste. The locationn is excellent , the decor eclectic and charming, the service personal. I wish I could have stayed longer!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2006, traveled on business
reviews.text: We just returned from five nights in Amsterdam where we stayed at the Seven Bridges Hotel. Location is perfect, a few blocks from Rembrandtsplein and multiple tram stops, a 10=15 minute walk from the Rijksmuseum, but quiet and peaceful at the same time. It's a wonderful retreat from the busy city. We also found many good restaurants within a few blocks, including Thai, Rijstaafel, and Italian. The room was lovely with a beautiful canal view. Though not huge, it was space enough and very homey. If you're looking for something more expansive, room #5 seemed large and had its own little outdoor patio (it was on the garden, not canal, side). Everything is clean and creatively decorated. Each day began sitting by the window eating the breakfast brought to our room on china and watching the passersby along the canal. There were vast quantities of breads, croissant, yogurt, sliced cheese and turkey, along with juice, coffee and tea. You can even make lunch with the leftovers and carry it with you for a picnic! My only recommendation would be to vary the breakfast a little - even if it's just changing the types of breads or pastries, or perhaps a different cheese or even slice of quiche. The hosts were unobtrusive but helpful when asked. They even let us make short calls to our kids back in the States for free, and let me check-in for our return flight on their computer. All in all, it's a wonderful place to stay-quiet, perfect location, lovely room and courteous, professional staff. We would definitely stay there again.
reviews.title: Loved Seven Bridges!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2006
reviews.text: Luckily I grabbed a Lonely Planet guide while in Paris for our last minute trip to Amsterdam and this hotel was recommended. Even last minute we only paid $140.00 per night (two full size beds) and it was well worth it. Such a charming place to stay - quiet, clean and hospitable. The morning breakfast delivered to your room on pretty china is such a wonderful addition; it included coffee or tea, juice, various breads and crossant plus cheese, yogurt and smoked turkey!!! In the cold of winter the heated towel bar in the bath was a huge plus. Some of the rooms have canal views and antiques. Its a short walk from Rembrandt Square and if you are so inclined, Barneys coffeehouse has expanded and there is a new location right next door which is very classy and fun. I would stay here again in a heartbeat!!!
reviews.title: Charming and lovely!!!!

Great stay at Seven Bridges Hotel
reviews.text: Just returned from a 5 day stay at Hotel Seven Bridges-a beautiful historic canal house very centrally located (an easy walk to Anne Frank ,House, Van Gogh Museum & other major Amsterdam attractions). We stayed in room #7 which had large windows overlooking a canal. The room was quite spacious and contained lovely antique furniture as well as a roomy bathroom which had beautiful white tiles accented with a floral design and the floor was done in a rustic ceramic(probably Italian) tile-this gave it all a very clean look & cleanliness is the operative word for the entire room. We loved being served our breakfast in our room while we sat in plush leather chairs at the exquisite marble table. The innkeepers, Gunter & Pierre, couldn't be more accommodating and they take great pride in the decor they have created. We had an opportunity to see room #5-which is like a palace! It's quite large & is appointed with some gorgeous antiques. It also has it's own garden space where one can sit & have breakfast & plan the day. There are also some great restaurants in the area within a 5-10 minute walk.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at the Seven Bridges for a week. We had one of the modest, street-level studios rather than one of the highly decorated upstairs rooms because that was what was available. This meant we had no breakfast provided by the hotel. At first, I was disappointed by the room itself and the lack of a convenient breakfast, but I soon got used to the lack of carpeting and began to realize how nice it was to have the kitchenette. We quickly found a nearby grocery and stocked up, then made our own breakfast each morning.
reviews.title: Seven Bridges worked out great for us!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled solo
reviews.text: Since we were lodging “outside” the main hotel, we never saw the management except when we arrived and when we left. Both of them seemed quite amiable and helpful, offering us a very useful town map as well as advice, etc., so I wish we had seen more of them. We never saw the maid service, either, but they came every day and did a good job of keeping things clean.
reviews.title: Loved Seven Bridges!!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The location was nearly perfect for our needs, since Seven Bridges is located midway between the train station and the museum district. We took a cab there when we arrived, which cost a lot, but by the time we left a week later, we knew which tram to use, and it was about a Euro to get back to the train station. If you wear good walking shoes, you can walk to almost every location in the City that is of tourist interest, which is what we did.
reviews.title: Perfect

In fact, the canal boat tours all paused at the end of our street, to allow passengers to photograph "our" canal and its line of bridges. We felt lucky to be staying where we were. At night, when the bridge arches are lit up, it is just magical.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I stayed at The Seven Bridges for 7 nights in June/July of 2007. Our stay at the Seven Bridges was excellent. The rooms had a lot of character and were decorated with amazing detail (as mentioned by many other reviews and you can see great pictures on the Seven Bridges website). We stayed in room number 10 which is at the very top of the building. The room was very warm and cozy and really gave the feeling of what it is like to live in a canal-side home with its views of the back garden and sloped roof - especially when laying in bed on a rainy morning and listening to the rain drops bounce off of the roof. Even the walk up the winding staircase to our room added to the character and charm of our stay. I agree with another reviewer who stated that walking to our room each night felt more like we were staying at a friend's home than in a hotel.
reviews.title: Perfect Accommodations

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This hotel is a high quality experience and offers something different to a larger, more corporate style of hotel. It is sited on what is usually described, with justification, as the prettiest canal in Amsterdam. The tour boats actually stop at the end of it to give passengers the chance to take photos. It is close to everywhere you are likely to want to visit, and yet we found it to be very quiet. The only use we made of public transport in a 5 day stay was the tram to and from the station at the beginning and end.
reviews.title: Loved It!
Wow
reviews.text: I love this extraordinary hotel. I have stayed there twice, May 99 and June 06. The rooms are the most beautiful examples of the long tradition of Dutch excellence in decoration using a charming ecclectic style. Each room is unique with beautiful oriental rugs, leather chairs, elaborate tilework, and mirrors which are cleverly placed to reflect architectural details. The excellent service is discreet, the rooms VERY clean. A true Amsterdam experience located two blocks from Rembrandtplein on the most beautiful canal in the city. I just would not stay anywhere else.

We had accommodations with two beds and two rooms (plus frig to keep food/drink available). Can't imagine a more inviting place to stay in Amsterdam!!

reviews.title: Fantastic hotel
reviews.text: I guess it depends on what a person likes, I like antiques and good beds with lots of covers, hot coffee and croissants served to my room on pretty china and friendly faces in the morning. My room was # 5 it was beautiful and spacious with it's own bath and a shower with wonderful and plentiful hot water. It had a terrace overlooking gardens that we spent alot of time on. Gunter and Pierre couldn't have been nicer, even when we caused that little electrical accident. I was able to see most of the other rooms before I left and would have stayed in any of them, I just happen to like the one with the terrace the best. If you stay there tell them Donna Hodges says hi.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: What a lovely to place to stay. It was so easy to book by phone having looked up the details on the internet and when we arrived we were made very welcome. Our room (the garden room, no.5) was beautifully furnished and had the bonus of a patio to sit ouside (although going through the bathroom to reach it seemed a little unusual to start with). Breakfast in the room was much nicer than going into a depersonalised dining room and was excellent, with croissants, a variety of bread (tasting deliciously homemade), cheese, meat, yoghurts and fruit. It was enough to keep us going with sandwiches for lunch too!

After my first day touring the city I came back to my room to find a beautiful bouquet of tulips and a box of chocolates. Overall I had a great time and really enjoyed my stay at the Seven Bridges.

reviews.text: Coming from Hamburg we are familiar with high priced parking lots. But man Amsterdam is cheeky. They will ask EUR 3,40 per hour ! So, if you want to stay over night ... ask at Seven Bridges for not as high piced alternatives.

description: Seven Bridges Hotel is a 300 year old charming canal house at the beautiful confluence of two canals in the historic heart of Amsterdam. Character and atmosphere are created by individually decorated stylish rooms: precious antiques from Baroque, Louis XVI, Empire, Biedermeier to Art Deco, from Sotheby's and Christie's; oriental carpets on wooden floors; handcrafted marquetry furniture - mirrors, tables, beds by a Dutch artisan. Welcome to charm, sophistication and a beautiful ambience inside and outside. The hotel now has AIR CONDITIONING - in all but the "cool" rooms 3 and A.
